title: Toddler choked to death on peas while having dinner with his family
text:
Two-year-old Austin tragically died after eating some peas (Picture: North News)

The father of a toddler who tragically choked to death on a pea has urged all parents to learn CPR.

A coroner ruled Austin Hardman, two, died accidentally from acute asphyxiation caused by the inhalation of food matter on 21 November last year.

At his inquest Austin’s father Daniel, 34, paid a moving tribute to his ‘perfect’ son as he told people to ‘do something to prepare’.

He said: ‘If anyone can learn CPR, all I can say is do it, because I had never thought in a million years I would ever be in a position where I would have to do what I did.

‘If people could do something to prepare themselves – God forbid that should ever happen to them – I cannot stress enough that they should take that opportunity.’

He added: ‘Myself and Emma were just blessed to have such a perfect little boy.

‘It is too short, but we were absolutely blessed by a little boy as beautiful as he was.

‘I just hope that nobody else ever has to go through this again.’

Austin was enjoying a pizza and popcorn night with his dad, mum Emma, 33, and older brother Noah, 4, at home in Haswell, County Durham, on the night of his death, the inquest heard.

Austin’s father is urging all parents to learn CPR (North News / NNP)

Austin’s dad urged all parents to learn CPR so they don’t have to go what his family went through (North News / NNP)

It was a tradition the family followed every Friday but Austin ‘was going through a fussy phase’ and didn’t want pizza, his dad told Coroner James Thompson.

Instead, Daniel gave Austin sugar snap pea pods so he wouldn’t feel left out.

In a statement read out in court, Daniel said: ‘Austin started coughing I thought he had put too much in his mouth and patted him to see if it would help.

‘I was actually going to tell him off for being greedy.’

One of the sugar snap peas had lodged in Austin’s vocal chord and obstructed his airway.

An ambulance was called and arrived after 20 minutes, having been delayed by four minutes when it missed a turning into the family’s road.

The coroner said evidence from a pathologist showed Austin’s condition would have begun deteriorating before the ambulance was even called and the extra minutes were unlikely to have made a difference.

The tragedy happened as the family was sat down to dinner on movie night (North News / NNP)

The coroner found Austin died by accidental asphyxiation (North News / NNP)

Mr Thompson said that despite the ‘sustained and best efforts’ of his father, the ambulance service and neighbours who had been called round, the pea ‘could not initially be dislodged’.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Austin was rushed to North Durham university hospital but staff were unable to save him.

The coroner added: ‘A subsequent post-mortem examination revealed an impacted yellow green pea in the vocal chords which, along with other food debris, on the balance of probability I find caused the blockage.’

Addressing the family, Mr Thompson said: ‘Austin’s death is indeed a tragedy and hearing the evidence today one cannot fail to be moved.

‘I do hope that in some small way what has happened today at the inquest has given you some understanding what happened to Austin.’
